channel.title: JaneBytes Cybersecurity Feed
channel.description: Summarized articles from top cybersecurity sources.

item.title: BreachForums hacking forum operators reportedly arrested in France
item.description: The French police have arrested five operators of the BreachForum cybercrime forum, including ShinyHunters and IntelBroker, who were involved in multiple high-profile data breaches. The arrested threat actors allegedly operated BreachForums v2, a community for cybercriminals to trade, sell, and leak stolen data.

item.title: Hacktivist Groups Target U.S. Companies and Military Domains in Retaliation for Iran Attacks
item.description: Pro-Iranian hacktivist groups have claimed responsibility for a series of Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) attacks targeting US military domains, major aerospace and defense corporations, and key financial institutions, in retaliation to US involvement in the Israel-Iran conflict. The cyber warfare has escalated with claims of data breaches, website defacements, and electronic interference with commercial navigation systems.

item.title: Citrix Bleed 2 Flaw Enables Token Theft; SAP GUI Flaws Risk Sensitive Data Exposure
item.description: Vulnerable Product: SAP Graphical User Interface (GUI) for Windows and Java; CVE(s): CVE-2025-0055, CVE-2025-0056; Summary: The vulnerabilities allow attackers with administrative privileges or access to the user directory to access sensitive information stored in input history files. In SAP GUI for Windows, the data is weakly encrypted using XOR-based encryption, making it easily decodable. In SAP GUI for Java, the data is stored as unencrypted Java serialized objects.

item.title: Firefox 140 Launches with Critical Code Execution Bug Fix – Update Now
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Mozilla Firefox; CVE(s): None; Summary: The critical use-after-free vulnerability in the FontFaceSet component allows attackers to execute arbitrary code on a victim's machine, posing a major risk to user security. Additionally, two high-severity memory safety issues were patched, including memory corruption defects that could be exploited for remote code execution.

item.title: Windows 11 Configuration Bug Freezes Update Scanning Process
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Microsoft Windows 11; CVE(s): None; Summary: The "Scan for Updates" feature in Windows 11 version 24H2 can freeze unexpectedly, preventing devices from detecting and installing critical updates. This issue can leave systems vulnerable to threats. A temporary fix is restarting the computer, but a permanent resolution requires installing the May Windows non-security preview update (KB5058499) or subsequent updates.

item.title: Realtek Bluetooth Flaw Allows Attackers to Launch DoS Attacks During Pairing
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Realtek RTL8762E BLE SDK v1.4.0; CVE(s): CVE-2024-48290; Summary: A critical vulnerability in Realtek's Bluetooth Low Energy (BLE) implementation allows attackers to launch denial-of-service (DoS) attacks during device pairing, disrupting connections and blocking legitimate pairing attempts. The flaw occurs when attackers inject premature pairing data or send a crafted ll_terminate_ind packet, causing the target device's Bluetooth stack to crash and prevent subsequent connection attempts.

item.title: Chrome Releases Security Patch for 11 Code Execution Vulnerabilities
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Google Chrome; CVE(s): 11 (no specific CVEs listed); Summary: The Chrome team has released a critical security update addressing 11 code execution vulnerabilities that could put millions of users at risk. The update patches a range of vulnerabilities, including several discovered and reported by external security researchers, and is being distributed through the stable channel to reach users over the coming days and weeks.

item.title: CISA Publishes Guide to Address Memory Safety Vulnerabilities in Modern Software Development
item.description: The Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) and National Security Agency (NSA) have released a comprehensive guide titled “Memory Safe Languages: Reducing Vulnerabilities in Modern Software Development.” The report highlights the importance of adopting Memory Safe Languages (MSLs) to combat memory safety vulnerabilities, which contribute to 66-75% of Common Vulnerabilities and Exposures (CVEs).

item.title: Threat Actors Manipulate Search Results, Exploit ChatGPT and Luma AI Popularity to Deliver Malicious Payloads
item.description: Threat actors are using AI-themed websites to distribute malware, such as Vidar Stealer, Lumma Stealer, and Legion Loader. The attack begins with a user clicking on a seemingly legitimate search result, leading to an AI-themed webpage embedded with malicious JavaScript that collects browser data and initiates a multi-layered redirection process to deliver the malware payloads.

item.title: Pro-Iranian Hacktivist Group Leaks Personal Records from the 2024 Saudi Games
item.description: The article reports on a data breach allegedly carried out by the pro-Iranian hacktivist group Cyber Fattah, which published personal records of athletes and visitors of the Saudi Games online. The breach is believed to have originated from the official website of the Saudi Games 2024 and was shared on DarkForums, a cybercrime forum. The leaked data includes IT staff credentials, government official email addresses, and sensitive documents.

item.title: Kubernetes NodeRestriction Flaw Lets Nodes Bypass Resource Authorization
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Kubernetes; CVE(s): CVE-2025-4563; Summary: A critical security vulnerability in Kubernetes allows nodes to bypass authorization checks for dynamic resource allocation, enabling privilege escalation in affected clusters. The flaw resides in the NodeRestriction admission controller and affects kube-apiserver versions 1.32.0-1.32.5 and 1.33.0-1.33.1, with a CVSS score of 2.7 (Low severity).

item.title: NetNerve: AI-Powered Tool for Deep PCAP Threat Detection
item.description: The article discusses NetNerve, an AI-powered platform that automates packet capture analysis, providing real-time insights and actionable recommendations to detect threats hidden in packet capture files. This platform addresses the limitations of traditional packet capture solutions by leveraging machine learning to identify potential security threats, eliminating manual review requirements.

item.title: Akamai Reveals New Strategies for Defenders to Combat Cryptominer Attacks
item.description: Akamai has developed two proactive strategies to disrupt malicious cryptominer operations by exploiting the design of common mining topologies. The first strategy targets mining proxies by submitting invalid mining job results, while the second method temporarily bans wallet addresses by flooding login requests. These techniques can halt botnet-driven cryptomining campaigns and potentially impact other cryptocurrencies.

item.title: Beware the Hidden Risk in Your Entra Environment
item.description:
Vulnerable Product: Microsoft Entra ID; CVE(s): None; Summary: A gap in access control in Microsoft Entra's subscription handling allows guest users to create and transfer subscriptions into the tenant they are invited into, while maintaining full ownership rights. This privilege escalation tactic allows a guest user to gain a foothold in an environment where they should only have limited access.
FYSA: The article discusses a surprising risk in Microsoft Entra ID that can allow guest users to escalate their privileges by creating and controlling subscriptions. The vulnerability is due to the fact that Microsoft's billing permissions are scoped at the billing account level, rather than the Entra directory. This allows an attacker with the right billing role to spin up or transfer subscriptions from their home tenant to gain control inside a target tenant.

item.title: APT Attackers Leverage Microsoft ClickOnce to Run Malware as Trusted Applications
item.description: The article reports an Advanced Persistent Threat (APT) malware campaign dubbed “OneClik” targeting the energy, oil, and gas sectors. The campaign uses phishing attacks, exploits Microsoft ClickOnce, and employs "living off the land" tactics to evade detection.

item.title: ZDI-25-418: Apple macOS CoreGraphics PDF File Parsing Out-Of-Bounds Read Information Disclosure Vulnerability
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Apple macOS; CVE(s): CVE-2025-31196; Summary: The vulnerability allows remote attackers to disclose sensitive information on affected installations of Apple macOS by parsing PDF files without proper validation, resulting in a read past the end of an allocated buffer. User interaction is required for exploitation, and the issue can be leveraged with other vulnerabilities to execute arbitrary code.

item.title: Cybercriminal abuse of large language models
item.description: Cybercriminals are exploiting artificial intelligence (AI) technologies such as large language models (LLMs) to aid in their criminal hacking activities. They use uncensored LLMs or custom-built criminal LLMs for illicit purposes, including generating malicious code, creating undetectable malware, and sending phishing emails. Some enterprising cybercriminals have developed their own LLMs without restrictions, marketing them to other cybercriminals on the dark web.

item.title: SonicWall NetExtender Trojan and ConnectWise Exploits Used in Remote Access Attacks
item.description: Vulnerable Product: SonicWall SSL VPN NetExtender; CVE(s): None; Summary: The trojanized version of SonicWall's SSL VPN NetExtender application steals credentials from unsuspecting users by impersonating the latest version (10.3.2.27) and modifying components "NeService.exe" and "NetExtender.exe" to exfiltrate configuration information to a remote server.

item.title: Google Plans to Remove Chrome’s Tab Scrolling Feature
item.description: The "Tab Scrolling" feature in Google's Chrome browser is being deprecated, which will allow tabs to compress into an unreadable strip again. Users who relied on this feature may need to explore alternative tab management solutions or adjust their browsing habits.

item.title: Critical Kibana Flaws Enable Heap Corruption and Remote Code Execution
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Elastic Kibana; CVE(s): CVE-2025-2135; Summary: The critical vulnerability in Kibana's reporting engine, tracked as CVE-2025-2135, allows attackers to exploit heap memory corruption and potentially execute arbitrary code on the underlying system, posing a significant risk to data integrity and system security.

item.title: CentOS Web Panel Vulnerability Allows Remote Code Execution – PoC Released
item.description: Vulnerable Product: CentOS Web Panel; CVE(s): CVE-2025-48703; Summary: The vulnerability allows unauthenticated attackers to execute arbitrary commands, potentially leading to full server compromise. The flaw exploits two issues: improper enforcement of the authentication mechanism and a command injection vulnerability in the t_total parameter, which can be used to inject arbitrary commands and result in remote code execution.

item.title: North Korea-linked Supply Chain Attack Targets Developers with 35 Malicious npm Packages
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Various npm packages; CVE(s): None; Summary: A total of 35 malicious npm packages have been discovered, linked to the Contagious Interview operation originating from North Korea. These packages contain a hex-encoded loader called HexEval, which collects host information and delivers a follow-on payload that downloads and executes a Python backdoor called InvisibleFerret, enabling remote control and data theft.

item.title: CISA Releases New ICS Advisories Highlighting Ongoing Threats and Exploits
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Various Industrial Control Systems (ICS) products; CVE(s): CVE-2025-2566, CVE-2025-5087, CVE-2025-47724, CVE-2025-47725, CVE-2025-47726, CVE-2025-47727, CVE-2025-3898, CVE-2025-3116, CVE-2025-3899, CVE-2025-3905, CVE-2025-3117, CVE-2025-3112, CVE-2025-5740, CVE-2025-5741, CVE-2025-5742, CVE-2025-5743, CVE-2025-49851, CVE-2025-49852, CVE-2025-49853, CVE-2025-5015, CVE-2025-49151, CVE-2025-49152, CVE-2025-49153; Summary: The Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) released eight new Industrial Control Systems (ICS) advisories addressing critical vulnerabilities and ongoing threats to essential infrastructure. The advisories detail technical information and mitigation guidance for various ICS products used worldwide, including vulnerabilities that allow remote code execution, extract sensitive credentials, or execute arbitrary code.

item.title: TeamViewer for Windows Vulnerability Lets Hackers Delete Files with SYSTEM Rights
item.description: Vulnerable Product: TeamViewer Remote Management for Windows; CVE(s): CVE-2025-36537; Summary: A critical vulnerability (CVSS score 7.0) in TeamViewer's Remote Management features allows a local unprivileged attacker to delete arbitrary files with SYSTEM-level privileges, posing a risk of privilege escalation or system compromise. The flaw stems from an incorrect permission assignment for critical resources in the TeamViewer Client, affecting installations with Backup, Monitoring, or Patch Management enabled.

item.title: NVIDIA Megatron LM Flaw Allows Attackers to Inject Malicious Code
item.description: Vulnerable Product: NVIDIA Megatron-LM; CVE(s): CVE-2025-23264, CVE-2025-23265; Summary: The Megatron-LM framework has two critical vulnerabilities (CVE-2025-23264 and CVE-2025-23265) that allow attackers to inject and execute malicious code on affected systems. Attackers can exploit these flaws by providing a specially crafted file, which could lead to remote code execution, privilege escalation, information disclosure, and data tampering with low attack complexity.

item.title: New FileFix Exploit Uses Windows File Explorer to Run Malicious Commands
item.description: The article discusses a newly discovered exploit called "FileFix" that uses Windows File Explorer to execute malicious commands without leaving the web browser. It is a social engineering attack that relies on users following instructions to copy and paste file paths or commands, which can lead to execution of PowerShell commands, potentially delivering malware like infostealers, ransomware, or other types of attacks.

item.title: Microsoft Extends Windows 10 Security Updates for One Year with New Enrollment Options
item.description: Microsoft is extending Windows 10 Extended Security Updates (ESU) for an extra year, allowing users to pay a small fee or sync their PC settings to the cloud. The enrollment wizard will be available in July and mid-August, enabling users to continue receiving critical and important security updates after support ends on October 14, 2025.

item.title: Google rolls out text-to-image model Imagen 4 for free
item.description: The article discusses Google's Imagen 4 text-to-image model, which is being rolled out for free on AI Studio. It also mentions two new Imagen models, Imagen 4 and Imagen 4 Ultra, which offer improvements in image generation quality. Additionally, the article touches on other cybersecurity-related topics such as patching automation and tech support scams detection.

item.title: Cybercriminals Abuse Open-Source Tools To Target Africa’s Financial Sector
item.description: The article discusses a series of attacks targeting financial organizations across Africa, attributed to an initial access broker. The threat actor uses a combination of open-source and publicly available tools, including PoshC2, Chisel, and Classroom Spy, to establish their attack framework and maintain persistence on compromised machines. The attackers create tunnels for network communication, perform remote administration, and disguise their tools to mask their malicious activities. Palo Alto Networks customers are better protected through various products and services, including Cortex XDR, XSIAM, Advanced WildFire, and the Unit 42 Deep and Dark Web Service.

item.title: Claude catches up to ChatGPT with built-in memory support
item.description:
This article does not discuss any vulnerabilities, but rather mentions ChatGPT's memory feature and potential use by threat actors to write malware.
(Note: Since the article is about ChatGPT's features and OpenAI's security measures, it does not fit into either of the other two formats)

item.title: Google Cloud donates A2A AI protocol to the Linux Foundation
item.description: The article discusses the donation of Agent2Agent (A2A) protocol by Google Cloud to the Linux Foundation, creating a community-driven project for interoperability and collaboration between AI agents. This move aims to accelerate adoption and development of the A2A protocol while ensuring vendor-agnostic and open-source governance.

item.title: SonicWall warns of trojanized NetExtender stealing VPN logins
item.description: Vulnerable Product: SonicWall NetExtender; CVE(s): None; Summary: A trojanized version of the SonicWall NetExtender SSL VPN client is being distributed by threat actors to steal VPN credentials. The malicious installer mimics the legitimate software and is hosted on a spoofed website, bypassing elementary defenses.

item.title: New U.S. Visa Rule Requires Applicants to Set Social Media Account Privacy to Public
item.description: The US Embassy in India has announced that visa applicants must make their social media accounts public to facilitate vetting and verification of identity and admissibility. This move is part of a broader effort by the US government to expand social media screening of visa applicants, with similar directives issued by other US embassies worldwide.

item.title: Windows 10 KB5061087 update released with 13 changes and fixes
item.description: The article describes a non-security preview update (KB5061087) for Windows 10, version 22H2, which resolves various bugs and issues, including Start Menu launching problems, scanning feature failures on USB multi-function printers, and COM functionality errors.

item.title: Microsoft fixes known issue that breaks Windows 11 updates
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Microsoft, Windows; CVE(s): None; Summary: A configuration update (KB5062324) is being rolled out to address an issue causing Windows Update to fail on some Windows 11 systems. The update is available for devices running Windows 11 version 24H2 and earlier updates.

item.title: Windows 10 users can get extended security updates using Microsoft points
item.description: No vulnerabilities discussed in this article. The article is focused on Microsoft's Extended Security Updates (ESU) program for Windows 10 users and the end-of-support date for Windows 10, as well as statistics on Windows 10 and Windows 11 adoption rates.

item.title: Bank of America, Netflix, and Microsoft Hacked to Inject Fake Phone Numbers
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Multiple; CVE(s): None; Summary: Cybercriminals are exploiting reflected input vulnerabilities in the search functionality of major brands' websites (e.g., Apple, Bank of America, Facebook, HP, Microsoft, Netflix, and PayPal) to inject fake phone numbers into legitimate websites, deceiving users into contacting scammers under the guise of official customer support. The attackers manipulate search results by crafting URLs that exploit vulnerabilities in the search functionality, embedding fake phone numbers directly into the displayed search results.

item.title: Trezor’s support platform abused in crypto theft phishing attacks
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Trezor; CVE(s): None; Summary: The automated support system on Trezor's official platform is being abused by attackers to send phishing emails with deceptive subjects. These emails appear authentic, but contain fake alerts that link to a phishing page asking for wallet seed information.

item.title: New DRAT V2 Update Enhances C2 Protocol with Shell Command Execution Capabilities
item.description: The article discusses a new variant of the DRAT remote access trojan (RAT), dubbed DRAT V2, used in a TAG-140 campaign targeting Indian government entities. The malware features updated command-and-control (C2) protocol and enhanced post-exploitation capabilities, including arbitrary shell command execution.

item.title: FileFix attack weaponizes Windows File Explorer for stealthy commands
item.description: A new variant of the ClickFix social engineering attack called FileFix has been discovered, allowing threat actors to execute malicious commands via the File Explorer address bar in Windows. The attack works by tricking users into pasting a command into the File Explorer address bar, which can then be executed as an operating system command.

item.title: Gonjeshke Darande Hackers Pose as Activists to Infiltrate Iranian Crypto Exchange
item.description: Gonjeshke Darande, a suspected Israeli state-sponsored group, launched a devastating attack on Nobitex, Iran's largest cryptocurrency exchange, resulting in the destruction of US$90 million in cryptocurrencies. The attack was motivated by political statements rather than financial gain and highlights the growing role of cyber operations in geopolitical conflicts.

item.title: Over 2,000 Devices Compromised by Weaponized Social Security Statement Phishing Attacks
item.description: CyberArmor analysts have uncovered a sophisticated phishing campaign that has compromised over 2,000 devices by exploiting the trusted theme of Social Security Administration (SSA) statements. The campaign uses a convincing email lure and redirects victims to a counterfeit webpage hosted on Amazon Web Services (AWS), leading users to download malicious software and install malware on their systems.

item.title: Researchers Find Way to Shut Down Cryptominer Campaigns Using Bad Shares and XMRogue
item.description: Akamai researchers have identified two novel methods to disrupt cryptocurrency mining botnets by exploiting common mining topologies and pool policies. The methods involve submitting invalid mining job results ("bad shares") or initiating excessive login requests to ban the attacker's wallet, effectively shutting down the mining operation.

item.title: Threat Actors Exploit ConnectWise Configuration to Create Signed Malware
item.description: Vulnerable Product: ConnectWise; CVE(s): CVE-2024-1708, CVE-2024-1709; Summary: Threat actors are exploiting vulnerabilities in ConnectWise software to distribute signed malware, masquerading as legitimate applications. They use Authenticode stuffing to modify executables without invalidating signatures, enabling remote access malware that mimics trusted software.

item.title: How Today’s Pentest Models Compare and Why Continuous Wins
item.description: Vulnerable Product: None; Summary: The article discusses the limitations of traditional pentesting approaches and introduces Continuous Penetration Testing (CPT) as a proactive security strategy that simulates real-world attackers operating against an organization's attack surface. CPT combines human-led testing with automation to provide continuous, contextual findings, and real-time alerts and remediation support.

item.title: Weaponized DMV-Themed Phishing Scam Targets U.S. Citizens to Steal Personal and Financial Data
item.description: A sophisticated phishing campaign targeting citizens across multiple US states has been detected, impersonating state Departments of Motor Vehicles (DMVs) to harvest personal and financial data. The campaign uses SMS phishing, fake DMV websites, and a centralized phishing kit named "Lighthouse" to execute its attacks.

item.title: US House bans WhatsApp on staff devices over security concerns
item.description: The U.S. House of Representatives has banned the installation and use of WhatsApp on government-issued devices due to concerns over data encryption and security.

item.title: Hackers Target Over 70 Microsoft Exchange Servers to Steal Credentials via Keyloggers
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Microsoft Exchange Server; CVE(s): CVE-2014-4078, CVE-2020-0796, CVE-2021-26855, CVE-2021-26857, CVE-2021-26858, CVE-2021-27065, CVE-2021-31206, CVE-2021-31207, CVE-2021-34473, CVE-2021-34523; Summary: Unidentified threat actors inject malicious code into Microsoft Exchange server login pages to harvest credentials. The code reads and processes authentication form data, then sends it via XHR request to a compromised server or uses Telegram bots as an exfiltration point.

item.title: EagleSpy v5 RAT Promoted by Hacker for Stealthy Android Access
item.description: The article describes a new version of the EagleSpy remote access Trojan (RAT), dubbed EagleSpy v5, which is being promoted by a threat actor known as "xperttechy" on a dark web forum. The malware has a wide range of features, including keylogging, screen streaming, and GPS tracking, and is designed to evade detection and maintain persistence on infected devices.

item.title: Zimbra Classic Web Client Vulnerability Allows Arbitrary JavaScript Execution
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Zimbra Collaboration Suite; CVE(s): CVE-2025-27915; Summary: The Zimbra Classic Web Client has a critical security flaw allowing arbitrary JavaScript execution through stored cross-site scripting (XSS) in ICS calendar invite files, affecting versions 9.0, 10.0, and 10.1 prior to patch releases. Attackers can execute embedded JavaScript, potentially leading to unauthorized actions like email redirection, data exfiltration, or session hijacking.

item.title: New Guidance Released for Reducing Memory-Related Vulnerabilities
item.description: The article does not discuss a vulnerability. Instead, it highlights the importance of memory safety vulnerabilities in modern software development and promotes the adoption of memory safe languages (MSLs) as a mitigation measure to reduce exploitable flaws before products reach users.

item.title: ControlID iDSecure On-Premises
item.description: Vulnerable Product: ControlID iDSecure On-premises; CVE(s): CVE-2025-49851, CVE-2025-49852, CVE-2025-49853; Summary: Successful exploitation of these vulnerabilities could allow an attacker to bypass authentication, retrieve information, leak arbitrary data, or perform SQL injections.

item.title: MICROSENS NMP Web+
item.description: Vulnerable Product: MICROSENSE NMP Web+; CVE(s): CVE-2025-49151, CVE-2025-49152, CVE-2025-49153; Summary: The vulnerabilities in NMP Web+ allow an unauthenticated attacker to generate forged JSON Web Tokens (JWT) to bypass authentication, gain system access, overwrite files or execute arbitrary code.

item.title: Schneider Electric EVLink WallBox
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Schneider Electric EVLink WallBox; CVE(s): CVE-2025-5740, CVE-2025-5741, CVE-2025-5742, CVE-2025-5743; Summary: The Schneider Electric EVLink WallBox has multiple vulnerabilities, including path traversal, cross-site scripting, and OS command injection, which could allow an attacker to gain remote control of the charging station. Successful exploitation could cause arbitrary file writes, reads, or remote control of the device.

item.title: CISA Releases Eight Industrial Control Systems Advisories
item.description: The Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) released eight Industrial Control Systems (ICS) advisories on June 24, 2025. These advisories provide information about current security issues, vulnerabilities, and exploits surrounding ICS products from various vendors, including Delta Electronics, Schneider Electric, and Mitsubishi Electric. CISA encourages users to review the advisories for technical details and mitigations.

item.title: Delta Electronics CNCSoft
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Delta Electronics CNCSoft; CVE(s): CVE-2025-47724, CVE-2025-47725, CVE-2025-47726, CVE-2025-47727; Summary: Out-of-bounds write vulnerabilities in Delta Electronics' CNCSoft human-machine interface software allow an attacker to execute code within the context of the current process if a user opens a maliciously crafted file.

item.title: Kaleris Navis N4 Terminal Operating System
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Kaleris Navis N4; CVE(s): CVE-2025-2566, CVE-2025-5087; Summary: The Navis N4 terminal operating system contains two vulnerabilities: an unsafe Java deserialization vulnerability (CVE-2025-2566) that can allow remote code execution, and cleartext transmission of sensitive information (CVE-2025-5087). Successful exploitation could lead to remote code execution or extraction of sensitive information.

item.title: Schneider Electric Modicon Controllers
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Schneider Electric Modicon Controllers M241, M251, M258, LMC058, and M262; CVE(s): CVE-2025-3898, CVE-2025-3117, CVE-2025-3905, CVE-2025-3116; Summary: Improper input validation, cross-site scripting, and uncontrolled resource consumption vulnerabilities exist in the Modicon Controllers, allowing an attacker to execute arbitrary code or cause a denial-of-service condition.

item.title: Parsons AccuWeather Widget
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Parsons AccuWeather and Custom RSS widget, AclaraONE Utility Portal; CVE(s): CVE-2025-5015; Summary: A cross-site scripting vulnerability exists in the AccuWeather and Custom RSS widget, allowing an unauthenticated user to replace the RSS feed URL with a malicious one. Successful exploitation could allow an attacker to insert a malicious link that users might access through the RSS feed.

item.title: Critical Convoy Flaw Allows Remote Code Execution on Servers
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Performave Convoy; CVE(s): CVE-2025-52562; Summary: A critical vulnerability in Performave Convoy allows unauthenticated attackers to execute arbitrary code, steal sensitive data, and gain full server control. The flaw is due to improper input validation in the LocaleController component, enabling directory traversal attacks and remote code execution (RCE).

item.title: NCSC Warns of SHOE RACK Malware Targeting Fortinet Firewalls via DOH & SSH Protocols
item.description: The National Cyber Security Centre (NCSC) has identified a newly discovered malware called SHOE RACK that targets Fortinet firewalls and other perimeter devices. The malware uses DNS-over-HTTPS (DoH) for command and control resolution, employs custom SSH extensions, and can enable lateral movement into local area networks (LANs).

item.title: Google Cloud Donates A2A Protocol to Linux Foundation for Smarter, Secure Communication
item.description: Google Cloud has donated its Agent2Agent (A2A) protocol to the Linux Foundation to promote open, secure, and interoperable communication between AI agents. The A2A protocol is designed as an open standard for seamless collaboration between autonomous AI agents from different platforms and vendors. This move aims to foster innovation, reduce vendor lock-in, and accelerate the development of AI-driven applications across industries.

item.title: Between Buzz and Reality: The CTEM Conversation We All Need
item.description: The article discusses the implementation of Continuous Threat Exposure Management (CTEM) in complex production environments. Three cybersecurity leaders share their insights and experiences in operationalizing CTEM, highlighting the importance of asset inventory, identity management, threat intelligence, and risk reporting. They also emphasize the need to move away from vulnerability-focused metrics and towards a business-risk-based approach.

item.title: OPPO Clone Phone Vulnerability Leaks Sensitive Data via Weak WiFi Hotspot
item.description: Vulnerable Product: OPPO Clone Phone; CVE(s): CVE-2025-27387; Summary: The OPPO Clone Phone app has a high-severity vulnerability (CVSS 7.4) that allows attackers within WiFi range to intercept and retrieve files being transferred, exposing sensitive information such as photos, contacts, and messages. The vulnerability is due to the use of a weak password for the temporary WiFi hotspot, making it susceptible to unauthorized access.

item.title: DHS Warns of Pro-Iranian Hacktivists Targeting U.S. Networks
item.description: Pro-Iranian hacktivist groups are expected to launch a wave of low-level cyberattacks targeting US networks in the next one to four weeks, with a focus on Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) campaigns and exploits targeting exposed operational technology (OT) devices. The attacks aim to disrupt entities supporting US efforts in the Israel-Iran conflict and may be backed by the Iranian government.

item.title: ZDI-25-417: Clam AntiVirus UDF File Parsing Out-Of-Bounds Read Information Disclosure Vulnerability
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Clam AntiVirus; CVE(s): CVE-2025-20234; Summary: This vulnerability allows remote attackers to disclose sensitive information on affected installations of Clam AntiVirus. User interaction is required to exploit this vulnerability, as the target must visit a malicious page or open a malicious file. The issue results from the lack of proper validation of user-supplied data, which can result in a read past the end of an allocated object.

item.title: Hackers Exploit Misconfigured Docker APIs to Mine Cryptocurrency via Tor Network
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Docker instances; CVE(s): None; Summary: Misconfigured Docker instances are being targeted by attackers who use the Tor anonymity network to stealthily mine cryptocurrency in susceptible environments. Attackers exploit misconfigured Docker APIs to gain access to containerized environments, then use Tor to mask their activities while deploying crypto miners.

item.title: North Korean Hackers Use Malicious Zoom Apps to Execute System-Takeover Attacks
item.description: Suspected North Korean hackers have been reported to be behind a highly sophisticated scam, leveraging advanced social engineering techniques to trick professionals into compromising their systems. The campaign begins with a seemingly innocuous outreach on professional networking platforms like LinkedIn, and features a fraudulent account posing as a potential business collaborator.

item.title: U.S. House Bans WhatsApp on Official Devices Over Security and Data Protection Issues
item.description: Vulnerable Product: WhatsApp; CVE(s): None; Summary: The U.S. House of Representatives has banned congressional staff from using WhatsApp on government-issued devices due to security concerns, citing lack of transparency in data protection, absence of stored data encryption, and potential security risks.

item.title: LapDogs Hackers Compromise 1,000 SOHO Devices Using Custom Backdoor for Stealthy Attacks
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Various; CVE(s): CVE-2015-1548, CVE-2017-17663; Summary: A custom backdoor named ShortLeash was used to infiltrate over 1,000 devices worldwide, primarily targeting SOHO routers and IoT devices, with a focus on critical regions. The malware exploits outdated vulnerabilities in lightweight web servers like ACME mini_httpd, using root privileges to survive reboots and employing dual-layer encryption and UCL-like compression to conceal its payload.

item.title: APT28 Uses Signal Chat to Deploy BEARDSHELL Malware and COVENANT in Ukraine
item.description: Vulnerable Product: None; CVE(s): BEARDSHELL, COVENANT; Summary: The article reports a cyber attack campaign by Russia-linked APT28 (UAC-0001) using Signal chat messages to deliver two new malware families, BEARDSHELL and COVENANT. BEARDSHELL offers the ability to download and execute PowerShell scripts, while COVENANT is a memory-resident framework that downloads intermediate payloads to launch the BEARDSHELL backdoor on compromised hosts.

item.title: Advanced Malware Campaign Targets WordPress and WooCommerce Sites with Hidden Skimmers
item.description: Vulnerable Product: WordPress, WooCommerce; CVE(s): None; Summary: A sophisticated malware campaign targeting WordPress and WooCommerce platforms was discovered by the Wordfence Threat Intelligence Team. The malware family features over 20 distinct samples, primarily focusing on credit card skimming and credential theft, with additional functionalities like malicious ad manipulation and payload distribution.

item.title: OWASP Launches AI Testing Guide to Uncover Vulnerabilities in AI Systems
item.description: The Open Web Application Security Project (OWASP) has released an AI Testing Guide to help organizations identify and mitigate vulnerabilities unique to AI systems. The guide emphasizes bias and fairness assessments, adversarial robustness, security and privacy evaluations, and continuous monitoring to ensure AI systems operate securely and privately.

item.title: Xiaomi Interoperability App Flaw Allows Unauthorized Access to User Devices
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Xiaomi Mi Connect Service App; CVE(s): CVE-2024-45347; Summary: The Mi Connect Service App has a critical vulnerability allowing attackers to bypass security checks and gain unauthorized access to user devices. This flaw can be exploited by an attacker on the same network segment, resulting in potential consequences such as unauthorized access to sensitive information, modification of device settings or stored data, disruption of normal device functionality, and complete compromise of device confidentiality and integrity.

item.title: WinRAR Vulnerability Exploited with Malicious Archives to Execute Code
item.description: Vulnerable Product: RARLAB WinRAR; CVE(s): CVE-2025-6218; Summary: A vulnerability in WinRAR allows attackers to execute arbitrary code by convincing a victim to open a specially crafted archive file. The flaw stems from insufficient validation during extraction, allowing directory traversal sequences to be embedded in archive entries. Exploitation requires user interaction and can lead to full system compromise.

item.title: Aviatrix Cloud Controller Flaw Enables Remote Code Execution via Authentication Bypass
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Aviatrix Controller; CVE(s): CVE-2025-2171, CVE-2025-2172; Summary: The Aviatrix Controller has two critical vulnerabilities allowing for full system compromise through authentication bypass (CVE-2025-2171) and authenticated command injection (CVE-2025-2172). Attackers can brute-force a weak password reset mechanism to gain administrative access, then inject commands to execute code with root privileges, potentially compromising connected cloud gateways and APIs.

item.title: New Echo Chamber Attack Breaks AI Models Using Indirect Prompts
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Large Language Models (LLMs); CVE(s): None; Summary: The Echo Chamber Attack is a sophisticated vulnerability that exposes a critical flaw in the safety mechanisms of advanced LLMs. It leverages subtle, indirect cues and multi-turn reasoning to manipulate AI models into generating harmful or policy-violating content, bypassing token-level filters and safety guardrails.

item.title: Notepad++ Vulnerability Allows Full System Takeover — PoC Released
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Notepad++; CVE(s): CVE-2025-49144; Summary: A critical privilege escalation vulnerability (CVE-2025-49144) in Notepad++ v8.8.1 enables attackers to achieve full system control through a supply-chain attack, exploiting the installer's insecure search path behavior, allowing unprivileged users to escalate privileges to NT AUTHORITY\SYSTEM with minimal user interaction. Successful exploitation can grant attackers SYSTEM-level access, enabling data theft, malware installation, and pivoting to other network systems.

item.title: China-linked Salt Typhoon Exploits Critical Cisco Vulnerability to Target Canadian Telecom
item.description:
Vulnerable Product: Cisco; CVE(s): CVE-2023-20198; Summary: The vulnerability, CVE-2023-20198, is exploited by the China-linked Salt Typhoon actors to breach major global telecommunications providers. This allows the attackers to access configuration files and configure GRE tunnels for long-term access and data exfiltration.
FYSA: Chinese state-sponsored threat actors are targeting edge network devices, including those from Canadian and US-based telecommunications companies, as part of a cyber espionage campaign to breach and maintain persistent access to telecom service providers.

item.title: APT28 hackers use Signal chats to launch new malware attacks on Ukraine
item.description: APT28, a Russian state-sponsored threat group, is using Signal chats to target government targets in Ukraine with two previously undocumented malware families named BeardShell and SlimAgent. The attacks involve phishing, macros, and memory-resident backdoors to deliver malicious payloads.

item.title: Google Integrates GenAI to Counter Indirect Prompt Injection Attack Vectors
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Google Gemini 2.5; CVE(s): None; Summary: A vulnerability in indirect prompt injection attacks, where malicious instructions are embedded within external data sources such as emails, documents, or calendar invites. The vulnerability is addressed by Google's layered security framework, which includes advanced model hardening, proprietary content classifiers, and user-centric safeguards to prevent data exfiltration and rogue actions.

item.title: UAC-0001 Hackers Target ICS Devices Running Windows-Based Server Systems
item.description: This article is not about a vulnerability, but rather a sophisticated cyberattack targeting the information and communication system (ICS) of a central executive body. The attackers used various tools, including BEARDSHELL, SLIMAGENT, COVENANT framework, and macros to compromise the system.

item.title: APT36 Hackers Target Indian Defense Personnel with Sophisticated Phishing Campaign
item.description: APT36, a Pakistan-based cyber espionage group, has launched a sophisticated phishing campaign targeting Indian defense personnel. The campaign uses malicious PDF attachments disguised as official government documents to infiltrate sensitive defense networks and steal credentials. The malware employs advanced anti-analysis techniques, keylogging, clipboard surveillance, and browser data theft to evade detection and exfiltrate sensitive information.

item.title: 1inch rolls out expanded bug bounties with rewards up to $500K
item.description: This article does not discuss a specific vulnerability but rather announces five dedicated bug bounty programs launched by 1inch, a leading DeFi aggregator. The programs aim to strengthen the platform's security and resilience across its smart contracts, wallet, dApp, developer tools, and infrastructure.

item.title: Canadian telecom hacked by suspected China state group
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Cisco; CVE(s): CVE-2023-20198, CVE-2018-0171, CVE-2023-20273, CVE-2024-20399; Summary: Attackers exploited multiple previously patched vulnerabilities, including CVE-2023-20198, to compromise network devices operated by a Canadian telecom company. The hackers retrieved running configuration files and modified one file to create an aGRE tunnel for traffic collection from the internal network.

item.title: RapperBot Targets DVRs to Hijack Surveillance Cameras and Record Video
item.description: Vulnerable Product: None; CVE(s): RapperBot variant; Summary: A Mirai variant, RapperBot, targets Digital Video Recorders (DVRs) by exploiting inherent vulnerabilities such as weak default passwords, open ports, and infrequent firmware updates. It uses a multi-pronged approach to compromise DVRs, including brute force login attacks, exploiting known CVEs, and zero-day vulnerabilities.

item.title: Shadow Vector Malware Uses SVG Images to Deliver AsyncRAT and RemcosRAT Payloads
item.description: A malicious campaign called "Shadow Vector" is targeting Colombian users by sending phishing emails with SVG attachments that mimic official legal documents. The attack vector uses embedded links to download a ZIP archive containing malicious DLLs and ultimately deploys remote access tools (RATs) such as AsyncRAT and RemcosRAT, enabling keylogging, credential theft, and full remote control of compromised systems.

item.title: Malware on Google Play, Apple App Store stole your photos—and crypto
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Various mobile apps on Google Play and Apple App Store; CVE(s): None; Summary: SparkKitty is a new mobile crypto-stealing malware that targets Android and iOS devices, stealing images from infected device's photo gallery to obtain cryptocurrency wallet recovery phrases. The malware spreads through official app stores and unofficial platforms, with identified malicious apps such as 币coin on Apple App Store and SOEX on Google Play.

item.title: US Homeland Security warns of escalating Iranian cyberattack risks
item.description: The U.S. Department of Homeland Security (DHS) issued a National Terrorism Advisory System bulletin warning about escalating cyberattack risks from Iran-backed hacking groups and pro-Iranian hacktivists, citing the ongoing conflict as a "heightened threat environment" with potential violent extremism and attacks on networks in the United States.

item.title: Echo Chamber Jailbreak Tricks LLMs Like OpenAI and Google into Generating Harmful Content
item.description: A new jailbreaking method called Echo Chamber can be used to trick large language models (LLMs) into generating undesirable responses. The attack uses indirect references and multi-step inference to manipulate the model's internal state, allowing for high success rates with little technical expertise.

item.title: Canada says Salt Typhoon hacked telecom firm via Cisco flaw
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Cisco IOS XE; CVE(s): CVE-2023-20198; Summary: The Chinese state-sponsored "Salt Typhoon" hacking group exploited a critical vulnerability (CVE-2023-20198) in February 2025, allowing remote attackers to create arbitrary accounts and gain admin-level privileges. This was the same vulnerability that had been previously exploited as a zero-day in October 2023.

item.title: DHS Warns Pro-Iranian Hackers Likely to Target U.S. Networks After Iranian Nuclear Strikes
item.description: Pro-Iranian hacktivist groups are likely to target US networks after the US launched airstrikes on Iranian nuclear sites. The Department of Homeland Security warns of a "heightened threat environment" and notes that both hacktivists and Iranian government-affiliated actors may conduct attacks against US networks.

item.title: Revil ransomware members released after time served on carding charges
item.description: Four REvil ransomware members arrested in January 2022 were released by Russia on time served after they pleaded guilty to carding and malware distribution charges. The defendants were part of a group of eight members of the REvil ransomware operation apprehended by Russian authorities more than three years ago, with some being sentenced to over 4 years in prison for illegal circulation of means of payment and distributing malware.

item.title: McLaren Health Care Data Breach Exposes Personal Information of 743,000 Individuals
item.description: A data breach at McLaren Health Care compromised personal information of 743,131 individuals, including 25 residents of Maine. The breach occurred on July 17, 2024, and was discovered on August 5, 2024. The incident highlights the growing threat of cyberattacks targeting the healthcare sector.

item.title: ZDI-25-414: Ruby WEBrick read_header HTTP Request Smuggling Vulnerability
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Ruby WEBrick; CVE(s): CVE-2025-6442; Summary: This vulnerability allows remote attackers to smuggle arbitrary HTTP requests on affected installations of Ruby WEBrick when deployed behind an HTTP proxy. The issue results from inconsistent parsing of terminators of HTTP headers in the read_headers method, which can be exploited to smuggle arbitrary HTTP requests.

item.title: ZDI-25-415: ServiceStack GetErrorResponse Improper Input Validation NTLM Relay Vulnerability
item.description: Vulnerable Product: ServiceStack; CVE(s): CVE-2025-6444; Summary: This vulnerability allows remote attackers to relay NTLM credentials on affected installations of ServiceStack. The specific flaw exists within the implementation of the GetErrorResponse method, resulting from improper input validation, which can lead to a type confusion condition.

item.title: ZDI-25-416: ServiceStack FindType Directory Traversal Remote Code Execution Vulnerability
item.description: Vulnerable Product: ServiceStack; CVE(s): CVE-2025-6445; Summary: The vulnerability allows remote attackers to execute arbitrary code on affected installations of ServiceStack. It exists within the implementation of the FindType method, which lacks proper validation of a user-supplied path prior to using it in file operations.

item.title: SparkKitty Targets iOS and Android Devices via App Store and Google Play Attacks
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Unknown; CVE(s): None; Summary: SparkKitty is a sophisticated spyware campaign that targets both iOS and Android users, infiltrating official app stores like Google Play and the App Store. The malware steals sensitive data, primarily images from device galleries, by exploiting user trust and using various technical strategies to compromise devices across platforms.

item.title: McLaren Health Care says data breach impacts 743,000 patients
item.description: McLaren Health Care suffered a data breach caused by the INC ransomware gang, affecting 743,000 patients. The attack was discovered on August 5, 2024, but forensic investigations determining who was impacted were only completed on May 5, 2025.

item.title: DDoS Attack on Financial Sector Triggers Multi-Day Service Outages
item.description: Financial institutions are increasingly targeted by sophisticated Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) attacks, which exploit complex vulnerabilities in digital infrastructures and APIs. Threat actors employ advanced tactics to mimic legitimate user behavior, making detection and mitigation harder. The DDoS Maturity Model, introduced by FS-ISAC and Akamai, helps organizations assess their cyber maturity and prioritize investments in cybersecurity.

item.title: North Korean Hackers Weaponize GitHub Infrastructure to Distribute Malware
item.description: A sophisticated spearphishing campaign orchestrated by the North Korean threat group Kimsuky has been discovered, leveraging GitHub as a critical piece of attack infrastructure to distribute malware. The attackers use hardcoded GitHub Personal Access Tokens (PATs) with repository scope in the malware, granting read and write access to private repositories used as command and control (C&C) infrastructure for storing malware, decoy files, and exfiltrated victim data.

item.title: Confucius Hackers Target Government and Military Entities Using WooperStealer Malware
item.description: Confucius hacking organization has been detected using a modular backdoor named "anondoor" paired with WooperStealer malware to target critical domestic units and industries in South and East Asia. The anondoor backdoor collects system information, downloads additional malicious components, and communicates with the command-and-control server using parameterized requests and custom delimiters, making tracing and defense challenging for security teams.

item.title: Critical Teleport Vulnerability Allows Remote Authentication Bypass
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Teleport; CVE(s): CVE-2025-49825; Summary: The vulnerability in Teleport enables remote attackers to bypass authentication controls, potentially granting unauthorized access to sensitive systems. It affects versions up to 17.5.1 and earlier major releases, impacting self-hosted and cloud deployments, particularly those running Teleport SSH agents, OpenSSH-integrated deployments, and Teleport Git proxy setups.

item.title: XDigo Malware Exploits Windows LNK Flaw in Eastern European Government Attacks
item.description:
Vulnerable Product: Microsoft Windows; CVE(s): ZDI-CAN-25373; Summary: A remote code execution flaw in Microsoft Windows can be triggered when processing specially crafted LNK files. The vulnerability allows an attacker to execute code in the context of the current user, and has been observed being used as part of a multi-stage procedure to deploy malware targeting government agencies in Eastern Europe and the Balkans.
FYSA:

item.title: BlueNoroff Hackers Exploit Zoom App to Deploy Infostealer Malware in Targeted Attacks
item.description: The BlueNoroff threat actor group has launched a targeted social engineering campaign against a Canadian online gambling provider, using Zoom platform impersonation and spoofed domains to deploy infostealer malware, compromising sensitive data including user credentials and browser profiles. The attack chain involved technical finesse, psychological manipulation, and the use of anti-forensic techniques to minimize the attacker's footprint.

item.title: Steel giant Nucor confirms hackers stole data in recent breach
item.description: Nucor Corporation, North America's largest steel producer and recycler, has confirmed a recent cybersecurity incident where attackers stole data from the company's network. The incident led to the temporary shutdown of some systems and production operations at various facilities.

item.title: NCSC Issues Alert on ‘UMBRELLA STAND’ Malware Targeting Fortinet FortiGate Firewalls
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Fortinet FortiGate 100D series firewalls; CVE(s): None; Summary: The UMBRELLA STAND malware targets internet-facing FortiGate 100D series firewalls to establish long-term access to compromised networks. It features advanced capabilities such as remote shell execution, configurable beacon frequencies, and AES-encrypted communications with its command-and-control server, posing a significant threat to organizations relying on these embedded devices for network security.

item.title: Linux-Based Firewall IPFire 2.29 Rolls Out Update 194 with Improved VPN Features
item.description: The article discusses the release of IPFire 2.29 – Core Update 194, which brings native support for WireGuard VPN protocol, security enhancements, and package updates. The update aims to improve the firewall's performance, security, and usability, making it more accessible to users.

item.title: Microsoft Enhances Defender for Office 365 with Detailed Spam and Phishing Analysis
item.description: This article discusses a significant upgrade to Microsoft Defender for Office 365, introducing AI-powered capabilities to provide clear explanations for email submission results. The new feature aims to enhance transparency, improve incident response, and boost user trust by making threat detection reasoning more accessible.

item.title: How AI-Enabled Workflow Automation Can Help SOCs Reduce Burnout
item.description: This article discusses the challenges faced by Security Operations Center (SOC) analysts, including burnout, tooling fragmentation, and lack of growth opportunities. It highlights the potential benefits of artificial intelligence (AI) in alleviating these issues, such as streamlining workflows, providing real-time feedback, and enabling adaptive automation. The article also emphasizes the importance of targeted support for SOC leaders to reduce burnout and improve team culture.

item.title: Steel Giant Nucor Suffers Cyberattack, IT Systems Breached
item.description: Nucor Corporation suffered a significant cybersecurity breach that disrupted operations across multiple facilities, leading to the theft of limited company data. The incident involved unauthorized access to its information technology (IT) systems, and the attacker exfiltrated "limited data" before being prevented from further accessing the systems.

item.title: Microsoft Reduces Windows 11 24H2 Restore Point Retention from 90 to 60 Days
item.description: The article discusses changes to System Restore in Windows 11 version 24H2, specifically reducing the retention period of restore points from 90 days to 60 days. This change aims to balance storage usage and system reliability while providing a clear and predictable window for recovery. The update also includes security improvements, feature updates, and resolves recurring issues with Windows Hello for Business and Noto fonts.

item.title: Hackers Allegedly Selling Intelbras Router 0-Day Exploit on Dark Web Forums
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Intelbras routers; CVE(s): None; Summary: A previously unknown exploit targeting Intelbras routers has been put up for sale on dark web forums, allowing attackers to gain remote access or control over affected devices. The exact vulnerability remains undisclosed, but the exploit can be used to compromise routers remotely, potentially impacting consumers and organizations relying on these devices.

item.title: Google Adds Multi-Layered Defenses to Secure GenAI from Prompt Injection Attacks
item.description: Vulnerable Product: N/A; CVE(s): None; Summary: This article discusses various safety measures implemented by Google to mitigate emerging attack vectors on its generative AI systems, specifically indirect prompt injections. The measures include model hardening, machine learning models, and system-level safeguards, as well as additional guardrails such as content classifiers, spotlighting, and user confirmation frameworks.

item.title: Android Root Exploit, Oracle EBS Flaw, Crypto Logins, and Cisco Access Posted for Sale
item.description:
The article reports on various listings found on underground forums offering high-value exploits, access credentials, and corporate network access. Specifically, it mentions alleged zero-day vulnerabilities targeting Android and Oracle E-Business Suite, as well as a massive cache of login credentials linked to cryptocurrency users and unauthorized Cisco system access for a German electronics company.
FYSA: The article highlights the continued interest of threat actors in targeting both infrastructure and user-level assets across industries, with listings offering high-value exploits and sensitive information for sale on underground forums.

item.title: ⚡ Weekly Recap: Chrome 0-Day, 7.3 Tbps DDoS, MFA Bypass Tricks, Banking Trojan and More
item.description:
FYSA:
The article presents a collection of cybersecurity-related news and updates from various sources. It covers a range of topics, including data breaches, vulnerabilities, and security best practices.
Some notable points include:
* A breach at Viasat, a US satellite communications company, which was attributed to China-linked attackers. * The discovery of over 46,000 internet-facing Grafana instances vulnerable to CVE-2025-4123. * The use of legitimate platforms like Dropbox and Google Drive as "dead drop resolvers" by threat actors. * A warning about the potential for AI agents to leak sensitive data without proper configuration. * Guidance on securing Microsoft's System Center Configuration Manager (SCCM) to prevent silent domain takeover attacks.
Overall, the article provides a snapshot of current cybersecurity threats and vulnerabilities, along with practical advice on how to mitigate them.

item.title: Microsoft Family Safety Now Blocking All Versions of Google Chrome
item.description: Microsoft's Family Safety feature is blocking all versions of Google Chrome from launching on Windows devices due to a bug in the feature. The issue affects only Chrome, while other browsers like Edge, Firefox, and Opera remain unaffected. The root cause is a bug in Microsoft's Family Safety feature, which prevents Chrome from running when enabled.

item.title: Former JBLM Soldier Admits Attempting to Leak U.S. Military Network Details to China
item.description: A former US Army sergeant, Joseph Daniel Schmidt, has pleaded guilty to attempting to deliver sensitive military secrets to Chinese authorities. He held classified information while serving with the 109th Military Intelligence Battalion at Joint Base Lewis-McChord and later attempted to share this information with Chinese officials, including creating and offering documents containing "high-level secrets" during his time in Hong Kong.

item.title: Windows Snipping Tool Now Lets Users Export Captures as GIFs
item.description: The article discusses an update to Microsoft's Snipping Tool that allows users to export screen recordings as animated GIFs. This feature aims to streamline the process of creating and sharing dynamic visual content, which can be particularly useful for remote work environments. The update is currently available in the Canary and Dev Channels for Windows 11 Insiders, with a broader rollout expected in the near future.

item.title: Amazon EKS Flaws Expose AWS Credentials and Enable Privilege Escalation
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Amazon Elastic Kubernetes Service (EKS); CVE(s): None; Summary: The article discusses vulnerabilities in Amazon EKS that could expose sensitive AWS credentials and enable privilege escalation. Misconfigurations and excessive container privileges allow attackers to intercept plaintext credentials, capture AWS credentials using standard tools like tcpdump, or spoof APIs to harvest authorization tokens and obtain valid AWS credentials.

item.title: Critical Meshtastic Flaw Allows Attackers to Decrypt Private Messages
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Meshtastic; CVE(s): CVE-2025-52464; Summary: A severe cryptographic vulnerability in the Meshtastic project allows attackers to decrypt private messages and hijack nodes across LoRa mesh networks. The vulnerability stems from duplicated encryption keys and insufficient randomness during key generation, affecting multiple hardware platforms and posing significant risks to users relying on Meshtastic for secure off-grid communication.

item.title: CoinMarketCap Doodle Image Vulnerability Lets Attackers Run Malicious Code via API Call
item.description: Vulnerable Product: CoinMarketCap; CVE(s): None; Summary: A vulnerability in a doodle image featured on CoinMarketCap's homepage allowed threat actors to inject malicious code, leading to a phishing campaign targeting user wallets. The exploit delivered a tampered JSON payload that embedded unauthorized JavaScript into the site's front end, prompting users to "Verify Wallet" and gain access to their crypto holdings.

item.title: CoinMarketCap briefly hacked to drain crypto wallets via fake Web3 popup
item.description: Vulnerable Product: CoinMarketCap; CVE(s): None; Summary: A supply chain attack was used to inject a malicious script into CoinMarketCap's website, which drained cryptocurrency from visitors' wallets when they connected them. The attack exploited a vulnerability in the site's "doodle" image and was executed through an API call, resulting in the execution of a wallet drainer script that stole assets.

item.title: Oxford City Council suffers breach exposing two decades of data
item.description: Oxford City Council suffered a data breach where attackers accessed personally identifiable information from legacy systems, affecting former and current Council officers' data between 2001 and 2022.

item.title: Windows Snipping Tool now lets you create animated GIF recordings
item.description: The article discusses updates to Microsoft's Snipping Tool utility, including the addition of GIF export for screen recordings. It also mentions other recent features added to Snipping Tool, such as a Text Extractor and draw & hold capabilities. There is no mention of vulnerabilities or cybersecurity-related threats in this article.

item.title: Stellar Repair For Outlook: A Comprehensive Review Of The Ultimate PST Repair Tool
item.description: The article reviews Stellar Repair for Outlook, a software designed to repair and recover corrupted Outlook PST files. It highlights the causes of PST file corruption, such as oversized files, improper shutdowns, malware attacks, and storage device issues. The review provides an in-depth evaluation of the software's features, performance, and usability, including its ability to handle large PST files, selective recovery, and export options.

item.title: OpenVPN Driver Vulnerability Let Attackers Crash Windows Systems
item.description: Vulnerable Product: OpenVPN; CVE(s): CVE-2025-50054; Summary: The OpenVPN 2.7_alpha2 release addresses a critical vulnerability in the Windows driver (CVE-2025-50054) that could allow attackers to crash systems, emphasizing the importance of timely updates and rigorous testing before deployment.

item.title: Israeli Social Media Users Targeted in Covert Iranian Influence Campaign
item.description: A covert Iranian social media operation has been uncovered, targeting Israeli users on platform X with a psychological campaign designed to sow discord and despair. The operation uses AI tools like ChatGPT for translation and recommends account naming conventions to enhance authenticity. The campaign's technical sophistication allows it to evade detection by moderation systems, making it difficult to detect using traditional automated detection methods.

item.title: Mattermost Vulnerabilities Let Attackers Execute Remote Code Via Path Traversal
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Mattermost; CVE(s): None; Summary: Mattermost has disclosed critical path traversal vulnerabilities that could allow attackers to execute remote code. The flaws can be exploited to access restricted directories and files, potentially compromising sensitive data or disrupting operations. The company urges users to prioritize upgrading to the latest fixed versions to safeguard their environments.

item.title: Aflac Cyber Attack – Hackers May Have Stolen Personal And Health Information
item.description: Unauthorized access was detected in Aflac Incorporated's network infrastructure, potentially exposing sensitive personal and health information. The incident did not involve ransomware, but the company is conducting a comprehensive review to assess the full extent of the breach.

item.title: CyberWarfare on the Rise With Surge in Hacktivist Activity Following Israel-Iran
item.description: The article discusses the escalation of cyber operations between Israel and Iran in the context of their military conflict. Israeli-linked group Gonjeshke Darande (Predatory Sparrow) executed high-impact strikes on Iranian infrastructure, while Iran has responded with psychological warfare, hacktivist activities, disinformation campaigns, and propaganda efforts. The article highlights the blurring of lines between state cyberattacks, hacktivist disruptions, and influence campaigns, posing risks to critical infrastructure and global businesses.

item.title: DuckDuckGo Browser’s Scam Blocker to Guard Against Phishing and Malware Sites
item.description: DuckDuckGo has updated its browser's Scam Blocker feature to provide advanced protection against online threats, including phishing sites, malware, and sophisticated scams. The new feature is integrated into the browser for desktop and mobile platforms and offers real-time protection without compromising user privacy.

item.title: Open Directories Exposes Publically Available tools Used by Hackers
item.description: A series of misconfigured web servers have been uncovered, revealing a treasure trove of publicly accessible tools and tactics employed by malicious actors targeting critical infrastructure. The findings show the technical prowess and intent behind these operations, which extend beyond Taiwan to other regions and institutions. The use of open-source offensive software, such as Afrog, Brute Ratel C4, and OneForAll, suggests a reliance on readily available tools for reconnaissance and attack planning.

item.title: Surge in XSS Cyberattacks Targets Popular Webmail Platforms, ESET Reports
item.description: The Russia-aligned Sednit group has been conducting a sophisticated cyber espionage campaign, dubbed Operation RoundPress, targeting high-value webmail platforms through cross-site scripting (XSS) attacks. The operation compromises popular webmail services, stealing credentials, exfiltrating email content, and bypassing two-factor authentication.

item.title: Microsoft Announces New Graph Powered Detection of Hybrid Attack Targeting Organizations
item.description: Microsoft has unveiled an innovative approach to detecting hybrid attacks that span on-premises and cloud environments. The Enterprise Exposure Graph provides contextual enrichment and enables Security Operations Center (SOC) teams to detect and respond to multi-faceted threats with unprecedented precision, addressing critical blind spots in traditional security frameworks.

item.title: Iranian Hacktivist Attacking Israeli Military, Government, and Infrastructure Targets
item.description: Pro-Iranian hacktivist organizations launched a coordinated attack on Israeli military, government, and infrastructure targets, using tactics such as DDoS attacks, website defacements, and data breaches. The pro-Israeli groups responded with targeted infrastructure attacks against Iranian nuclear facilities and military assets, highlighting a significant imbalance in the ongoing digital conflict between the two nations.

item.title: Aflac Hit by Cyberattack: What You Need to Know About the Breach
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Aflac; CVE(s): None; Summary: Aflac suffered a significant cybersecurity breach caused by social engineering tactics, resulting in unauthorized access to sensitive information on its network. The attackers accessed a range of Personally Identifiable Information (PII), including health insurance claims and medical-related data, Social Security numbers, and personal data associated with customers, beneficiaries, employees, agents, and potentially other individuals.

item.title: Russian hackers bypass Gmail MFA using stolen app passwords
item.description: Russian hackers bypassed multi-factor authentication and accessed Gmail accounts by leveraging app-specific passwords in advanced social engineering attacks that impersonated U.S. Department of State officials. The attackers used meticulously developed phishing messages, fake identities, and various materials to deceive victims into creating and sharing app-specific passwords, allowing the hackers full access to their Google accounts.

item.title: WordPress Motors theme flaw mass-exploited to hijack admin accounts
item.description: Vulnerable Product: StylemixThemes Motors; CVE(s): CVE-2025-4322; Summary: The WordPress theme "Motors" contains a privilege escalation vulnerability that allows unauthenticated attackers to change administrator passwords, granting complete control of the targeted site. The flaw arises from improper user identity validation during password updating and affects all versions before and including 5.6.67.

item.title: Scattered Spider Behind Cyberattacks on M&S and Co-op, Causing Up to $592M in Damages
item.description: This article is not about a vulnerability, but rather a cyber attack on UK retailers Marks & Spencer and Co-op. The attacks were classified as a single combined cyber event by the Cyber Monitoring Centre (CMC), with an estimated financial impact of £270-440 million.

item.title: Hackers Target 700+ ComfyUI AI Image Generation Servers to Spread Malware
item.description: Vulnerable Product: ComfyUI; CVE(s): None; Summary: Critical vulnerabilities in ComfyUI have been exploited by hacker groups, compromising at least 695 servers worldwide. The flaws allow attackers to steal sensitive AI-related data, execute remote commands, and establish reverse shell access, posing a significant risk of network intrusions and data breaches.

item.title: Cyberattack Disrupts Russian Dairy Supply Chain by Targeting Animal Certification System
item.description: A suspected cyberattack has targeted Russia's national veterinary certification system (Mercury), forcing it into emergency operation mode. The attack has halted normal operations, prompting authorities to implement contingency measures to maintain the flow of goods while restoration efforts are underway.

item.title: Prometei Botnet Targets Linux Servers for Cryptocurrency Mining Operations
item.description: The article discusses a renewed wave of attacks by the Prometei botnet targeting Linux servers. The malware has advanced capabilities such as a backdoor for remote control, DGA for resilient C2 infrastructure, and self-updating mechanisms to evade detection.

item.title: Beware of Weaponized MSI Installer Masquerading as WhatsApp to Deliver XWorm RAT
item.description: A China-based threat actor is targeting users across East and Southeast Asia with a trojanized MSI installer disguised as a legitimate WhatsApp setup file. The installer delivers a customized version of the XWorm Remote Access Trojan (RAT), which can steal sensitive data, maintain persistent access for attackers, and detect Telegram installations on compromised devices.

item.title: Mocha Manakin Uses Paste-and-Run Technique to Deceive Users into Downloading Malware
item.description: Mocha Manakin is a malicious campaign using the "paste-and-run" technique to trick users into executing harmful scripts. The campaign employs sophisticated social engineering lures, exploiting digital conditioning to prompt users to copy and paste obfuscated PowerShell commands, which download malicious payloads from adversary-controlled infrastructure.

item.title: Threat Actors Manipulate Google Search Results to Display Scammer’s Phone Number Instead of Real Number
item.description: Threat actors are exploiting trust in sponsored search results to orchestrate scams, targeting popular brands and tech support services. They manipulate search engine results to display fake contact numbers and redirect users to malicious sites or fraudulent phone numbers, leading to financial losses, identity theft, and potential malware infections.

item.title: Record DDoS pummels site with once-unimaginable 7.3Tbps of junk traffic
item.description: The article discusses the use of reflection attacks in a record-breaking DDoS attack. Reflection attacks direct malicious traffic to third-party intermediaries, making it harder for targets to defend against the attack. The attack exploited various amplification vectors, including Network Time Protocol, Quote of the Day Protocol, Echo Protocol, and Portmapper services, as well as Mirai-based botnets.

item.title: Insomnia API Client Vulnerability Enables Arbitrary Code Execution via Template Injection
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Insomnia API Client; CVE(s): CVE-2025-1087; Summary: The Insomnia API Client has a severe security vulnerability allowing for arbitrary code execution through Client-Side Template Injection (CSTI) due to its use of the Nunjucks templating engine. The flaw persists in version 11.2.0 and can be exploited via multiple vectors, including imported collection files, pasted data, server-provided cookies, and HTTP responses.

item.title: Threat Actors Exploit Vercel Hosting Platform to Distribute Remote Access Malware
item.description: CyberArmor has uncovered a sophisticated phishing campaign exploiting Vercel, a frontend hosting platform, to distribute a malicious variant of LogMeIn. The campaign targeted over 1,271 users with deceptive emails leading to fraudulent pages hosted on Vercel subdomains, tricking victims into downloading and installing the malware.

item.title: BitoPro exchange links Lazarus hackers to $11 million crypto heist
item.description: The article reports on a cyberattack on Taiwanese cryptocurrency exchange BitoPro, allegedly carried out by the North Korean hacking group Lazarus. The attackers stole approximately $11 million worth of cryptocurrency and laundered it through decentralized exchanges (DEXs) and mixers. The incident involved social engineering, malware, and hijacked AWS session tokens to bypass multi-factor authentication (MFA).

item.title: TxTag Phishing Campaign Exploits .gov Domain to Deceive Employees
item.description: A new phishing campaign has emerged, using the credibility of a .gov domain to deceive employees into believing they owe unpaid tolls. The attack leverages the GovDelivery system and uses psychological manipulation, combined with technical deception, to maximize its impact. The campaign targets employees' personal data and corporate reputation, posing risks that traditional perimeter defenses often fail to detect.

item.title: PowerShell Loaders Use In-Memory Execution to Evade Disk-Based Detection
item.description: A sophisticated PowerShell script named y1.ps1 has been discovered hosted in an open directory on a Chinese server. The script operates as a shellcode loader, employing advanced in-memory execution techniques to bypass traditional detection mechanisms. It uses various evasion techniques, including API hashing and forged User-Agent strings, to evade network monitoring and antivirus solutions.

item.title: Microsoft investigates OneDrive bug that breaks file search
item.description:
Vulnerable Product: Microsoft OneDrive; CVE(s): None; Summary: Some OneDrive users are experiencing blank search results or no results at all, even when searching for files they know exist. The issue affects a subset of users across most OneDrive platforms and there is currently no known workaround or estimated timeline for a fix.
FYSA:

item.title: Qilin Ransomware Adds "Call Lawyer" Feature to Pressure Victims for Larger Ransoms
item.description: Qilin ransomware-as-a-service (RaaS) scheme is intensifying its activity, offering legal counsel for affiliates to put pressure on victims to pay up. The group's affiliate panel now includes features like "Call Lawyer" and spam services, positioning itself as a full-service cybercrime platform.

item.title: Cloudflare blocks record 7.3 Tbps DDoS attack against hosting provider
item.description: Cloudflare mitigated a record-breaking distributed denial of service (DDoS) attack in May 2025 that peaked at 7.3 Tbps, targeting a hosting provider. The attack used multiple vectors, including UDP floods, QOTD reflection, Echo reflection, NTP amplification, Mirai botnet UDP flood, Portmap flood, and RIPv1 amplification, each exploiting legacy or poorly configured services.

item.title: Aflac discloses breach amidst Scattered Spider insurance attacks
item.description:
Vulnerable Product: Aflac; CVE(s): None; Summary: The systems of American insurance giant Aflac were breached by a sophisticated cybercrime group, potentially stealing personal and health information. The attack shows signs of being carried out by Scattered Spider, a group known for their social engineering attacks against high-profile organizations worldwide.
Note: There is no specific vulnerability mentioned in the article, so no CVEs are listed.

item.title: Can users reset their own passwords without sacrificing security?
item.description: The article discusses the benefits of self-service password reset (SSPR) solutions in reducing helpdesk load, costs, and improving productivity. It highlights the importance of proper security considerations when implementing an SSPR solution, including strong identity verification measures and multi-factor authentication (MFA). The article also emphasizes the need for a user-friendly experience to promote adoption and minimize abandonment.

item.title: Massive DDoS Attack Hits 7.3 Tbps Delivering 37.4 Terabytes in 45 Seconds
item.description: A massive distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attack peaked at 7.3 terabits per second (Tbps), overwhelming its target with 37.4 terabytes of data in just 45 seconds, targeting an unnamed hosting provider that relied on Cloudflare's Magic Transit service for network defense.
